instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message:
not liquid damaged.

board had a powering issue, I fixed by replacing the U4700. now the board can boot up.

but...

sometime I get black screen, no image, no backlight, I can hear sound and keyboard's will lit up.
sometime I get picture and everything else are fine.
also sometime when waking up from sleep or put the display to sleep, I get backlight but no picture or no backlight and no picture.
can also cause the system to crash.

Built-in LCD screen doesn't show up in system information.

[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/fONjrXg.jpg[/IMG]




[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/XMD0ajX.jpg[/IMG]


[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/mNv2N3q.jpg[/IMG]



I've already tried another display and new lcd flex cable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: You lifted the bracket on the LCD connector when removing the cable didn't you?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message:
yes, but not sure about a previous technician as this has been opened before.

you know something tell me :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: Never lift it! Probably fucked connector or cable. Or the conductive tape that ground the board to the case at the LCD connector is touching the pins.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message:
now I'm confused 

I thought you meant to lift the flip then you remove the cable, see my pic:

[img]https://i.imgur.com/4pclmI8.jpg[/img]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: I never lift it as it tends to fuck up. It is fine just sticking it in. Is the conductive tape under the cable not touching anything? I bet it is folded under the board or touching the connector pins.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message:
you might be right about the conductive tape, they are everywhere. 

I've post result after I find a way to isolate..

[img]https://i.imgur.com/sHA72UW.jpg[/img]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: It connects the board to the case, not on the cable. If the board was out you have had to peel that tape away.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: thanks Duke, you was right. After I isolated the leg pins of the connector with kapton tape, haven't had any problem for 2 days. crossed fingers!

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: Oh GREAT,  I just had one of these the other week, waiting on a replacement keyboard, and yes, I've flipped up the top-latch on the metal FPC connector too; for future reference, how are you supposed to extract the flex from the board connector... or don't at all?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: hold the connector with the flip closed with your finger then gently pull the flex out with your other hand's fingers.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: So basically treat it like an old friction fit FPC socket?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-00045 - MBr 12" 2015 - Built-in screen becomes undetected
threads.message: and if you take the board out make sure the conductive tape is in place and not touching the pins.
